item.title: 19 Awesome Side Quests Hidden In Cyberpunk 2077
item.description:
Cyberpunk 2077 remains extremely expansive, and within Night City and Dogtown, V can easily get caught up in the whirlwind of the wild characters within, and involve themselves in the lives of these wacky characters and their stories. Cyberpunk 2077 doesn’t just have quests and side jobs that are shown to them, there are some secret quests in Cyberpunk 2077 just waiting to be discovered.

With so much to do in Night City, it’s no surprise that there are some secret quests that even the most veteran of players might not know about. To continue finding things to do in Night City, look to these awesome hidden side quests in Cyberpunk 2077 to see if you’ve completed them all.

Updated on March 4, 2025, by Jake Fillery: There are some amazing side quests in Cyberpunk 2077 that most players might have missed. While the main missions and Phantom Liberty are extremely exciting, there are true gems lurking in Night City and Dogtown that most players are going to want to find and complete so that they can earn valuable rewards and have new experiences. Listed below, is an abundance of missable and hidden quests in Cyberpunk 2077 that players should definitely keep an eye out for.

19 I’m in Love with My Car

Acquire a Free Car from an Abandoned Warehouse

  • Location: Northside Warehouse, north-east of Watson
  • How to Acquire: Complete Act One
  • Rewards: Quadra Type-66 "Hoon"

Sure, V might not be the right age to be a pro-racer, nor do they have the time and the ability, but that doesn't mean they cannot indulge in some fun. This secret quest is short and sweet, but it will reward players with a pretty cool-looking vehicle, the Quadra Type-66 "Hoon", a secret car that will be waiting for them in a warehouse.

The vehicle itself has great top speed and acceleration, and its design even comes fitted with two machine guns. It's always nice to find a secret in Night City, especially one that awards players with a vehicle for their troubles.

18 Love Rollercoaster

Fix a Broken Rollercoaster to Make Memories with Johnny

  • Location: Eden Beach, Coastview, Pacifica
  • How to Acquire: Complete Act One
  • Rewards: None

While there is no reward for this quest in a physical sense, players will be rewarded in fun and good times with their best pal Johnny Silverhand. The quest has players fix up an old rollercoaster on Eden Beach, where V and Johnny can buckle in for the ride of their life that doesn't involve guns and corpos.

It might be a minor side job, but it's still secretive and a lot of fun for players who want to spend quality time with Johnny outside his nihilistic ways and the murder that comes with it, permitting a chance to just have a fun ride without the drama.

17 I’ll Fly Away

Give Scorpion the Funeral He Would Have Wanted

  • Location: Mobile Camp, Rocky Ridge, the Badlands
  • How to Acquire: Complete Riders on the Storm and speak to Mitch Anderson
  • Rewards: Stinger, Action Figure, 2,303 XP, 3,454 Street Cred

I'll Fly Away is another minor side job, but it's one that is very easy to miss if players continue through Panam's quest chain without interacting with Mitch Anderson, as this quest will not be available if players help the Aldecaldos move camp across the Badlands, and for the sake of the Aldecaldos, this sweet quest is one to experience.

The quest itself involves V and Mitch giving his pal Scorpion the funeral he would have wanted, and players even receive a new weapon and some loot for helping. It's always nice to help a friend, especially when V themselves are grieving the loss of their own best friend with Jackie now gone.

16 Happy Together

Understand Barry’s Pain and Prevent His Suicide

  • Location: Megabuilding H10, Watson
  • How to Acquire: Complete Act One
  • Rewards: None

Happy Together will be one of the first side jobs that players will uncover in Night City as it will activate immediately in Act 2 after players have met Johnny Silverhand. The quest itself involves two worried cops as they try to check in on V’s neighbor, Barry Lewis, a former NCPD cop who hasn’t been seen in days and grieves alone at the loss of his friend.

If V decides to talk to Barry and just leave it there, then Barry will end up dead in a few days. However, V can travel to the Columbarium in North Oak and find the grave of Barry’s friend Andrew – a turtle. V can take this knowledge to the cops outside of Barry’s apartment and save his life by allowing people to show that they understand his grief.

15 Machine Gun

Find Regina Jones’ Rhianna-Loving Smart Pistol

  • Location: Alley in Vista del Rey, Heywood
  • How to Acquire: Complete Act One
  • Rewards: Skippy (Iconic Smart Pistol)

Venturing to Vista del Rey in Heywood, players will find a corpse with a rather special weapon: Skippy. Skippy is a beloved gun for a few reasons. Not only does it have a pretty good set of Iconic modifiers and uses a Smart Link to aim for the head, but it also speaks to V with a sassy and loyal charm. Yet, that charm runs out after 8 in-game days, when Skippy asks to be returned to his owner: Regina Jones.

Players can return Skippy to Regina, or decide to keep the gun for themselves. Regardless of their choice, it’s worth noting how fun and secret Skippy is, for he has two firing modes: Puppy-Loving Pacifist and Stone Cold Killer. If players choose the former, then after 100 kills he will permanently switch to the latter, and vice versa.

14 The Highwayman

Uncover the Sad Fate of Two Lovers for a Sweet Bike

  • Location: Behind the Gun-O-Rama in Rancho Coronado, Santo Domingo
  • How to Acquire: Pick up the photo of James and Josie in the garage
  • Rewards: ARCH Nazare “Itsumade”

Within Rancho Coronado East, players can find a garage with a decal of a skeletal horse just behind the Gun-O-Rama shop. Doing so will proceed with The Highwayman, a hidden quest in Cyberpunk 2077 that will have V and Johnny investigate the fate of the two lovers photographed within the garage, James and Josie. When finding James in Japantown, an investigation truly begins.

While The Highwayman might not have the greatest ending for two lovers, it’s still one worth completing to find out how cruel Night City can be, and to obtain a stolen Tyger Claw motorcycle: the ARCH Nazare “Itsumade” that will provide players with one of the best motorcycles in Cyberpunk 2077 .

13 Murk Man Returns Again Once More Forever

Obtain Night City’s Very Own Batmobile

  • Location: Rocky Ridge mine tunnel in the Badlands
  • How to Acquire: Complete Ghost Town
  • Rewards: Rayfield Caliburn “Murkmobile”

Once players have aided in Panam Palmer’s quests with Ghost Town, players can actually head back into the same tunnel where V and Panam fought and killed the Wraiths and Raffen Shiv. Within these tunnels, there’s a dark secret found within one of the abandoned shipping containers, and inside is a Rayfield Caliburn “Murkmobile”, indicating that a vigilante uses these tunnels to move around – perhaps much like a famed DC Comics hero with a thing for bats?

Sadly, there is no Murk Man to stop V here, and only a data shard will prove that a vigilante roams Night City and the Badlands. V can take the Murkmobile for their own garage, but as far as this quest goes, there isn’t much action other than the thrills of high speeds with a new ride from the Badlands.

12 Dressed to Kill

A Photoshoot Gone Wrong Provides V With a New Ride

  • Location: Desert Film Set in Rocky Ridge, Badlands
  • How to Acquire: Visit the Desert Film Set
  • Rewards: Thorton Colby CX410 “Gran Butte”

For the Vs out there who like to explore the Badlands, feel free to check out the desolate Desert Film Set location at Jeff’s Dirt Track, which has quite a few corpses scattered throughout. While V might spot a Trauma Team vehicle leaving the area, all the evidence around and the data shards suggest a photoshoot that didn’t exactly go as planned thanks to the Wraiths.

While this is a quest that tells a visual story rather than having V get into the combat themselves, it’s still interesting to see the life of Night City go on, and even more interesting to claim yet another free vehicle for V’s collection with the abandoned Thorton Colby CX410 “Gran Butte”.

11 1R-ONC-LAD

A Scavenger Hunt in the Petrochem Stadium to

  • Location: Green shipping container in the EBM Petrochem Stadium, Dogtown
  • How to Acquire: Access Dogtown with the Phantom Liberty DLC
  • Rewards: Eurodollars, Skill Shard (dependant)

Within the Petrochem, players can uncover the flickering and sparking body of a robot, waiting for help. Interacting with the robot reveals itself as 1R-ONC-LAD, and now V has to explore the Peotrchem Stadium in search of computers and scavenger drops to rebuild 1R-ONC-LAD’s database so that it may once again be repaired.

1R-ONC-LAD is like the Cyberpunk 2077 Pinocchio, but is providing a robot with a sense of morality a good idea? Players can either wipe 1R-ONC-LAD’s memory, leave the bot alone to complete its revenge, or reprogram it so that it becomes a talented guitarist – the third option provides V with Eurodollars and a Skill Shard a few days later if V returns to 1R-ONC-LAD’s now abandoned location.

10 Bullets

Battle a Secret Cyberpsycho and Speak With MaxTac

  • Location: Junguji in Downtown, City Center
  • How to Acquire: Talk to Zane Jagger in Junguji
  • Rewards: None

The Bullets side quest is a unique surprise that shows how dangerous Night City is. A fine clothing establishment such as Jinguji seems like a safe place for the rich to splash some eddies, but when venturing here and talking to the clerk, a Cyberpsycho breaks through – forcing V to engage in a tough boss fight until MaxTac arrives.

The main secret from this quest comes from the MaxTac employee, who players can identify as Melissa Rory, a MaxTac lieutenant who was a former Cyberpsycho herself – thus reinforcing the idea that MaxTac is just programmed Cyberpsychos.

9 The Prophet’s Song

Uncover Global Conspiracies Involving Garry the Prophet

  • Location: Urmland Street in Kabuki, Watson
  • How to Acquire: Talk to Garry the Prophet
  • Rewards: None

Outside Misty’s Esoterica, players can find Garry the Prophet, a character who incessantly rambles on about lizard people and other absurd conspiracies that plague Night City. Players need to talk to Garry a few times throughout their ventures, and then one day, Garry will give V a mission to investigate an area of Kabuki.

The quest involves Johnny and V on a stakeout against Maelstrom and an unnamed organization, and the quest involves a bizarre conspiracy that still remains unsolved. Where is Garry, and who took him? Perhaps Garry’s conspiracies hold merit after all.

8 Kold Mirage

Discover the Body of the Legendary Netrunner, Rache Bartmoss

  • Location: Municipal landfill at Red Peaks, Badlands
  • How to Acquire: Complete Ghost Town
  • Rewards: Memory Wipe, Reboot Optics, Short Circuit, Sonic Shock, System Collapse (x5 Quickhacks)

Kold Mirage is another secret quest that some players might have missed due to both its obscurity and its location deep within the Badlands. If V ever feels like returning to the spot where Dex left them for dead in the Badlands, they can find an old freezer that has the corpse of Rache Bartmoss, a Night City legendary Netrunner.

The quest then takes players to the Afterlife where they can uncover some of Rache Bartmoss’ secrets with the Netrunner, Nix, and doing so will provide a few Quickhacks. While the reward is nothing special, it’s a fun quest that deepens the lore.

7 Shape Of A Pony

Discover The Body Of A Fake Johnny Silverhand

  • Location: Biotechnia Flats, Badlands
  • Acquired: Purchase Porsche 911 Turbo Cabriolet (930) for €$74,000
  • Potential Rewards: Porsche 911 Turbo Cabriolet (930)

Once players purchase the Porsche 911 Turbo Cabriolet (930), they will receive a mysterious message from one of their favorite Fixer's, Muamar Reyes. This text involves the mystery around the recently purchased vehicle, and how it has disappeared, with the driver nowhere to be seen. Luckily, V receives a text of the last known location.

Venturing here, players will find a funny sight, as a Johnny Silverhand impersonator lies dead on the floor. Players can loot this corpse and find further clues as to where their new vehicle is hiding. It's a cute quest that will see Johnny Silverhand's legacy live on.

6 Moving Heat

Sneak Into Barghest's Garage And Steal The Quadra Sport R-7 Charon Vehicle

  • Location: EBM Petrochem Stadium, Dogtown
  • Acquired: Complete the Firestarter mission in Phantom Liberty's campaign
  • Potential Rewards: Quadra Sport R-7 Charon

If players want to get their hands on a pretty cool new ride, then they are going to need to complete Moving Heat. If players have gone through the Phantom Liberty campaign, they will recognize the Quadra Sport R-7 Charon Vehicle as a true beauty, now locked away in the garage of Barghest's infinite army. Luckily, a quick text from a netrunner is going to aid them.

Players can mess this quest up, so stealth is essential when working with this mysterious netrunner. In doing so, they will earn themselves the vehicle, which would have otherwise been unavailable if players ignored this cryptic texter, or decided to do things the loud way.

5 FF06B5

Investigate A Community-Led Mystery Still Unsolved

  • Location: Biotechnia Protein Farms
  • Acquired: Enter the Biotechnia Protein Farm's shack
  • Potential Rewards: n/a

FF06B5 is going to throw players for a loop, as it's a true mystery that still hasn't exactly been solved all the way through. The quest itself is unmarked, and players are given mere clues rather than directions as to where to go next. If players are looking for something secret to do in Night City, trying to solve FF06B5's mystery will certainly have players wasting hours.

The puzzle has truly perplexed gamers, and the community continues to try and discover more to this quest in the in-game world. From a secluded shack, to a mysterious savior, FF06B5 will have players scratching their heads and fearing what exactly is going on in Night City.

4 Feed Teh Cat

Acquire A Pet Cat

  • Location: China Town, Watson
  • Acquired: Search a barrel in Megabuilding H10: Atrium for a data shard
  • Potential Rewards: Nibbles the cat

Heading to Megabuilding H10: Atrium, players can take a left from their apartment door into a small alleyway where they will discover a trash can with a data shard poking out of it. This data shard simply reads "Feed teh Cat", and it's a secret unmarked quest that requires players to place a food bowl at the same location and head out into the world to come back a few hours later.

Whilst it's not the most exciting quest in the world, it will reward players with Nibbles, a hairless cat that will become V's pet. Nibbles will hang out in V's apartment, purring and meowing in V's presence. It's a cute and secret side quest worth jumping into so V's apartment gets a furless friend.

3 Voodoo Treasure

Unlock A Secret Voodoo Boys Stash For Extra Loot

  • Location: The Needle, Dogtown
  • Acquired: Listen to Aurore and Aymeric's conversations in I've Seen That Face Before
  • Potential Rewards: 8,000 Eurodollars, Rook

Dogtown is filled with secrets, and one of them can be obtained by eavesdropping. Through Phantom Liberty's main quest I've Seen That Face Before, players can listen to Aurore Cassel and Aymeric Cassel's conversation, where they will discuss Slider. Upon dealing with the twins, players can loot a Blind_N_Dead data shard to unlock themselves a missable quest in Cyberpunk 2077 .

This quest is rather simple, and it will take players to the Needle in Dogtown, where they can discover a secret stash filled with Eurodollars and other useful items from the Voodoo Boys. It's not a hard quest, and the rewards are rather nice, as who wouldn't want a new Iconic Pistol?

2 This Corrosion

Unlock The Power Of The Blackwall

  • Location : Watson, Kabuki Market
  • Acquired : Receive a mysterious text after Somewhat Damaged mission
  • Rewards : Militech Canto Mk.6 or Erebus

Whilst this mission may be a short one, it’s easily one of the best side jobs in Cyberpunk 2077 due to its secrecy and reward. Not many people will know about the hidden items that can be looted during the Somewhat Damaged quest from Phantom Liberty , since these requirements are locked behind the path where players betray Songbird and help Solomon Reed in the Firestarter mission. However, This Corrosion adds further mystery and power to the game.

Players are given instructions via text messages from AIs that are beyond the Blackwall. It’s scary to think that they know everything about V and instruct them to visit a Netrunner at the Kabuki Market to place the Behavioral Chip they found from the Cerberus Unit into a weapon of their choice, a weapon capable of corrupting those it touches.

1 Venus in Furs

A Fun Night with Meredith Stout Provides Lewd Rewards

  • Location: No-Tell Motel in Kabuki, Watson
  • How to Acquire: Keep Meredith Stout alive during The Pickup
  • Rewards: Sir John Phallustiff (Iconic Melee Weapon)

For those still in Act One of Cyberpunk 2077 , they might not have a great impression of Meredith Stout. Meredith is a hard-edged and no-nonsense operations manager for Militech, and V can provide her with a hard time when meeting her during The Pickup. Some players might elicit to not use her help, and in doing so, she will be replaced by Anthony Gilchrist – with Meredith dead and buried.

However, if players follow Meredith’s plan at the All Food’s Plant with Maelstrom, she will still be alive, and be rather thankful to V and later in the game will invite them to a No-Tell Motel for some raunchy fun. A one-night stand isn’t all players will get, as an extremely lewd and overpowered melee weapon can be acquired from the bed they slept on.

item.title: Pokemon Fan Creates Regional Forms For Phantump and Trevenant
item.description:
Summary

  • Pokemon fans enjoy creating regional forms, like for Phantump and Trevenant, combining different types and abilities.
  • The regional Trevenant is described as being more intimidating after punishment by a Legendary Pokemon.
  • There are many examples of creative regional forms shared by the Pokemon community, showcasing impressive designs.

A Pokemon fan has created regional forms for Phantump and its evolution, Trevenant, and shared the result online. Introduced in Gen 7 with the release of Pokemon Sun and Moon , regional forms have become a very popular theme among Pokemon fans. As a result, there are often impressive works imagining even more regional forms than those that officially exist.

The Pokemon franchise has four regions with regional forms, the most recent being Paldea, the setting for Pokemon Scarlet and Violet . Ironically, although it is a feature that has been present in the franchise for some time, the list of Pokemon with a regional form is not long, and several have yet to receive this alternative design. This time, a talented Pokemon fan expressed their creativity with one critter, giving it a makeover that hasn't gone unnoticed by other fans.

Redditor ArkhamLegion showed what it would be like if Phantump and Trevenant had regional forms. Phantump, one of the Gen 6 Pokemon, appears with a slightly grayish mask, while its body is made up of bright red and orange flames. According to the lore they created, the pocket monster gains these colors when struck by lightning, and the result is a combination of different types, with this Phantump being a Ghost/Fire-type with the Natural Cure ability, and the hidden Flame Body ability. The artist also shows what the shiny variant of this regional Phantump would look like.

Pokemon Fan Designs Intimidating Regional Forms for Phantump and Trevenant

The same goes for Trevenant, which has been given a regional form that makes it even more intimidating. Its body is a slightly faded brown, and the other parts of the monster are a bright shade of orange, including the horn-like branches on its head. The artist's lore says this regional Trevenant has been punished by a Legendary Pokemon, and sentenced to be struck by lightning, hence the mark on the Pokemon's body. This Ghost/Fire-type's ability is Lightning Rod, while its hidden ability is also Flame Body. They also show what the shiny regional Trevenant would look like, and the color palette is just as impressive as the regular variant.

ArkhamLegion's work is impressive, and one of many regional form ideas the community often shares. There's no shortage of examples, such as the player who created a regional form for Tinkaton's evolutionary line, giving the popular pocket monster a design using references from other Pokemon. Another player went a mile further and caught the eye by creating regional forms for 13 different Pokemon, showing inventive designs for characters such as Snorunt, Cottonee, and Applin, demonstrating just how far the creativity of Pokemon fans can go.

item.title: NYTs Strands Hints, Tips, and Answers for Today, March 4, 2025
item.description:
Today’s Strands puzzle puts a creative spin on traditional word games, merging the straightforward appeal of word searches with a deeper, theme-based twist. Tackling this puzzle requires an ability to spot patterns, making it both rewarding and occasionally tricky.

For those who know how to play Strands , you know it can be a real brain-teaser. If you find yourself hitting a wall, this guide is here to lend a hand. Packed with tips, hints, spoilers, and more, it’s designed to help you navigate the puzzle and come out on top.

The NYT Games Strands It's Our Game-iversary! #366 March 4, 2025

The Strands puzzle for today has the clue It's Our Game-iversary! It has eight things to find: the Spangram and seven themed words.

NYT Strands Spangram Tips and Theme Hints

If you want to see some hints that won't ruin any of the answers for this puzzle game, you can find three in the sections below. Open up the expandable sections with the "Read More" link below each one.

General Spangram Hint 1

General Spangram Hint 2

General Spangram Hint 3

Spoilers for Today's New York Times Strands

If a spoiler or two would help you win today's Strands , but you don't want to save up for in-game hints, you can find some below. Look into each of the sections to see one themed word and a screenshot of where it goes.

Spoiler 1

Spoiler 2

The Answer to the NYT It's Our Game-iversary! Strands

Need the full answer to the It's Our Game-iversary! Strands ? Inside the section below is the Spangram, all the themed words, and where each goes inside this free-to-play game.

Today's Strands Explained

If you want to see an explanation for the answer of this innovative puzzle game, you can find it below. Inside the expandable section is a breakdown of what the clue, the themed words, and the Spangram all have in common with one another.

Want to play? Check out the New York Times Games Strands website available on almost any device with a browser.

item.title: Every Tomb Raider Game, Ranked
item.description:
Few video game protagonists have stood the test of time to last as long as the likes of Mario or Sonic The Hedgehog. One of these characters would be Lara Croft . When Tomb Raider burst onto the scene in 1996, it was very rare for a female protagonist to be the leading playable character in a video game, with the only noteworthy exception being Samus from the Metroid series.

Tomb Raider exploded into a mega-franchise that continued for many years, then found itself rebooted with a new series of games that enjoyed tremendous success during the 2010s. Which are the best Tomb Raider games ? Which are the worst?

Updated March 3, 2025 by Mark Sammut: In February 2025, a new Tomb Raider compilation hit store shelves, covering three of the more divisive entries in the franchise. Tomb Raider 4–6 Remastered is primarily for diehards who want to replay The Last Revelation and Chronicles and don't mind giving The Angel of Darkness another try.

Every Tomb Raider Game

Tomb Raider has a long and storied history, one that spans more than 15 games across a plethora of platforms and console generations. Lara Croft has been around the world multiple times, and that looks set to continue. The table below lists every Lara Croft game , along with its original release date, developer, and publisher.

Select a game to go to its ranking.

Games

Original Release Date (North America)

Developer

Tomb Raider

Eidos-Montreal

Tomb Raider 4-6 Remastered

February 14, 2025

Aspyr

Aspyr

Certain games were released on both home and handheld consoles; in these cases, the former will be the priority since the latter are, generally, not the same.

23 Tomb Raider: The Angel Of Darkness (2003)

Lara's Broken Adventure

When Lara made the leap from the PlayStation to the PlayStation 2, fans were met with a grittier and darker game that disappointed plenty of players. The lack of polish to the controls, a camera the players ended up fighting more than the in-game enemies, and a plethora of bugs and glitches made The Angel of Darkness a mess to play.

The developers openly admitted to suffering from a severe lack of leadership with too much ambition for the project leading to many production issues resulting in the game players were given in 2003. The Angel of Darkness has neat ideas and a potentially interesting story, but it is difficult to recommend in its current form. Out of all of Lara Croft's adventures, this would be the best candidate for a remaster or remake.

22 Tomb Raider: Chronicles (2000)

Franchise Fatigue

The developers at Core Design had already become fatigued by Tomb Raider by the time Chronicles rolled around. Consequently, they attempted to kill off Lara Croft in the previous game but Eidos was determined to keep the franchise going as a cash cow. This led to the final game for Lara on the original PlayStation.

With a mixed reception, the consensus is that Chronicles was nothing bad but very uninspired, forgettable, and with little to no difference to distinguish it from previous installments. This is just another PS1 Tomb Raider game, an adventure that goes in one ear and out the other.

21 Tomb Raider Reloaded (2023)

An OK Mobile Diversion

Tomb Raider 's only new game to be released in the 2020s so far, Reloaded went by largely unnoticed, which makes sense since the franchise is predominantly a console staple rather than a mobile heavyweight (despite producing quite a few projects for the latter). Several big IPs have tried their hand at iOS and Android gaming, and while there are a couple of great releases, they tend to fall by the wayside quite quickly. Tomb Raider Reloaded is no exception, although that does not mean the game has nothing to offer. In fact, it is a decent mobile project, even if it might struggle to satisfy long-time fans who want a traditional Lara Croft adventure.

Reloaded 's gameplay loop revolves around short-burst stages filled with traps and enemies. The controls and mechanics are stripped down quite a bit, but they do complement this type of release. Unfortunately, like so many mobile games before and after it, Reloaded 's monetization is frustrating at the best of times. That said, the Netflix version removes a lot of the ads and greatly improves the overall experience.

20 Tomb Raider: The Prophecy (2002)

A Respectable But Forgettable Portable Adventure

Swapping from a third-person adventure to a Zelda -esque overview, Lara jumped to the Nintendo Game Boy Advance with a mildly successful title. Tomb Raider: The Prophecy was praised for its impressive graphics and sound for a Game Boy Advance title.

However, it received criticism for its dull gameplay, little to no story to drive the repetitive action set pieces, and various other complaints. It all led to a title that even die-hard Tomb Raider fans have forgotten had existed over the years. While it is far from brilliant, The Prophecy is a serviceable handheld entry in the franchise.

19 Tomb Raider: Apocalypse (2002)

(Almost) Lost To Time

Arguably the hardest Tomb Raider project to find, Apocalypse was a 4-episode game released through Sky Gamestar, a service that allowed customers to play quite an extensive list of titles by paying either for a session or daily. The service launched in 2001 and ended in 2015, making its library difficult to access legitimately. While unknown to people outside the UK, Sky Gamestar had games based on quite a few recognizable IPs ( Ben 10 , Avatar , Codename: Kids Next Door , Dexter's Laboratory , Ed, Edd n Eddy , Hulk , and Scooby-Doo! ), along with popular originals like Beehive Bedlam .

For years, Tomb Raider: Apocalypse was considered lost media, as were many Gamestar projects; however, 2023 changed all of that, as most of the service's games were discovered and made available in some form or another. Regardless of quality, the fact that Apocalypse can be experienced nowadays is fantastic. That said, is it actually worth playing? Well, the game is an acquired taste, especially since it does not play like any of the other Tomb Raider releases. An old-school cinematic platformer, Apocalypse very much seems ripped from the late '80s and early '90s, albeit with OK visuals that benefit from the episodes visiting quite a few different locations. The gameplay is fine but slow and punishing, and it gets repetitive quite quickly. Still, Apocalypse is quite substantial, containing dozens of levels across its episodes.

18 Lara Croft: Relic Run (2015)

Tomb Raider Is A Good Fit For An Endless Runner

This mobile spin-off took its liberties to present the series to a casual audience. Essentially a Tomb Raider version of the mobile game Temple Run , Relic Run does contain some of the franchise’s trademark qualities that allow the game to stand out in the Endless Runner genre.

It’s more of an evolution in the endless platforming genre, as elements like wall-running and utilizing weapons are injected into the game. All things considered, Relic Run is a great way for casual fans to be introduced to the series, even if it is too one-dimensional.

17 Tomb Raider: Curse Of The Sword (2001)

Impressive For The Hardware

The GBA's Curse of the Sword is the sequel to 2000's Tomb Raider which came out on the Game Boy Color. Similar to that title, the 2001 release takes players on a small but satisfying adventure. This time, the campaign primarily takes place in city locations and opts for larger stages rather than its predecessor's shorter levels.

Curse of the Sword looks pretty decent for a Game Boy Advance game, particularly its backdrops. Even if the environments are not especially exotic, the game does its best to make them visually striking.

16 Lara Croft And The Temple of Osiris (2014)

Really Fun Co-Op Top-Down Shooter

In 2014, the Tomb Raider series tried its hand at arcade-inspired gameplay with co-op pushed to the forefront. The Temple of Osiris accommodates up to four characters, including Lara, and all of them have their own special abilities and traits.

It has a top-down view of the action, which takes away some of the franchise's charm since the camera is so limited. Apart from that, however, the game is good fun for multiple players, making it a small-scale but enjoyable entry in the series.

15 Tomb Raider (2000)

Better Than It Has Any Right To Be

2000's Tomb Raider took Lara to Nintendo's Game Boy Color, and the franchise handled the transition to handheld surprisingly well. Naturally, expectations need to be tempered since the hardware could not possibly replicate the home console experience, but Tomb Raider does an admirable job of replicating Lara's iconic moveset.

As the game maintains a relatively slow pace, this is certainly not an action-heavy experience; however, the campaign offers a good mix of puzzles, exploration, and cutscenes. While not a must-play title, this release would fit snugly in any GBC collection.

14 Tomb Raider 3 (1998)

Very Good, But Safe Sequel

While not as beloved as the first two games in the series, Tomb Raider 3 is a solid threequel that made everything bigger than ever before. Admittedly, this did come at the loss of most of the mystery and suspense found in the prior entries.

There was also a severe lack of innovation that caused Tomb Raider 3 to feel more akin to an expansion pack to the second game rather than a big-budget sequel. Despite these criticisms, Tomb Raider 3 is a highly enjoyable classic romp in the series, one that should please anyone fond of Lara's previous two adventures.

13 Tomb Raider: The Last Revelation (1999)

Nothing New But Nothing Bad

Best remembered these days for being a failed effort by the series to kill off Lara Croft and introduce a new lead, The Last Revelation is still a solid affair that represents the style and gameplay choices of gaming back in the day.

While not held in as high esteem as Tomb Raider and its sequel, The Last Revelation is arguably the most ambitious entry of the classic era after the original two masterpieces. Rather than going for a globe-trotting adventure, the campaign is set entirely in one location, Egypt, allowing for a fairly immersive experience by the franchise's standards. The cutscenes are also quite cinematic.

12 Tomb Raider 4-6 Remastered (2025)

The Best Way To Experience Lara Croft's Most Awkward Era

With the original trilogy receiving a remaster, another compilation containing the next three entries made sense on paper. However, that plan came with one major issue: Tomb Raider 4, 5, and 6 are nowhere near as highly regarded. OK, The Last Revelation is a classic Lara adventure that can easily stand alongside Tomb Raider 3 , even if it does not quite reach the same heights as the first two masterpieces. However, Chronicles and The Angel of Darkness are among the worst Tomb Raider games . On the one hand, their inclusion reduces the appeal of this compilation since they are difficult to sell as exciting replays or first runs, particularly The Angel of Darkness . Conversely, the original games set the bar low enough that there is plenty of room for improvement. If done right, The Angel of Darkness might be worth playing for the first time.

Tomb Raider 4-6 Remastered is in a tough spot. Aspyr deserves all the credit in the world for putting together an impressive remaster that preserves and modernizes a part of gaming history, and the developer seems to have treated these three polarizing titles with the same care and attention as Tomb Raider 1-3 Remastered . This compilation contains, without question, the best versions of The Last Revelation , Chronicles , and The Angel of Darkness . They look great, incorporate modern controls well enough, and combine to offer about 30 hours of content. The Last Revelation is almost worth the price of admission on its own, while Chronicles is a fine enough romp through Lara's history. Unfortunately, while better than its original incarnation, The Angel of Darkness is still not particularly worth experiencing, except during completionist runs. The game is still a baffling mess that struggles to create a cohesive whole.

11 Tomb Raider 1-3 Remastered Starring Lara Croft (2024)

A Good Way To Experience The Original Trilogy

Tomb Raider 1-3 Remastered is a difficult compilation to properly rate since it is simultaneously the best way to experience the PS1 trilogy, all the while not being particularly impressive. Just to be crystal clear, this release remasters the games by updating the visuals and providing the option to use modern controls, although the latter can be swapped for the original versions. The package's changes and improvements do not go much further than that, so anyone expecting any tweaked content or fresh ideas will likely be disappointed. Consequently, if someone has already played through the classic entries and does not have any desire to revisit them, they will probably get next to nothing out of Tomb Raider 1-3 Remastered .

While perhaps not everything it could have been, this 2024 release still preserves three influential games that are not particularly accessible on modern systems outside of PC. The new controls are a welcome alternative, even if the levels are clearly designed to accommodate tank controls rather than modern movement. The games are still brimming with creativity and personality, with the first title being especially great.

10 Lara Croft Go (2015)

Great Mobile Game

It seemed as if the Tomb Raider series had explored all avenues as far as gaming genres were concerned, only for Lara Croft Go to utilize the turn-based gaming style. The game is entirely puzzle-based and relies on crucial movements the player makes.

This makes it one of the smartest smartphone games out there, as Lara has to be navigated in such a way that players need to strategize their next moves. Overall, it’s an effective change from the norm the series engaged in.

9 Lara Croft And The Guardian of Light (2010)

Very Different Gameplay But Nails What It Is Trying To be

Remarkably, the top-down camera approach doesn’t hinder the fun factor of this spin-off. The game makes puzzle-solving and platforming its greatest strength as these are bolstered by the beautiful visuals and balance with action sequences.

The slight negative here is the cheesy storyline, which is far removed from the Tomb Raider formula. Still, it’s easy to overlook that considering the remarkable replay value courtesy of Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light 's fun gameplay, great level design, and utilization of traditional Tomb Raider gameplay.

8 Shadow Of The Tomb Raider (2018)

A Good Conclusion To A Great Trilogy

The third entry in the rebooted Tomb Raider series by Square Enix garnered positive reviews for bringing Lara back to a more visually appealing jungle setting. It also retained the gameplay that made the previous two games classics in gamers' eyes, although this entry focuses more on exploration and platforming than action. Shadow of the Tomb Raider also includes some great underwater sections.

Though it pleased fans, the game didn't rise to the bar that the previous entries set due to a disappointing story and safe gameplay that felt very "been there, done that." While a solid experience in its own right, Shadow of the Tomb Raider ended the Survivor trilogy on a slightly underwhelming note.

7 Tomb Raider: Underworld (2008)

A Great Conclusion To A Somewhat Overshadowed Trilogy

After the series had returned with Anniversary and Legend , Tomb Raider made its biggest comeback with Underworld . This entry mixed classic and new mechanics with pleasing visuals from the Xbox 360 and PS3 era. Underworld led to an entry that fans felt was a satisfying ending for the classic Lara Croft.

Naturally, the game was not considered perfect; the combat system felt a bit dated, the story was surprisingly short, and much like with Angel Of Darkness , Underworld could not quite get a proper grasp of the camera. Still, this is a fun adventure game that nails the franchise's trademark exploration and platforming while showcasing Lara at the height of her cool.

6 Tomb Raider: Legend (2006)

A Legend Is Revised And Respected

After the disappointing Angel Of Darkness , Legend was intended as the true return to form as a brand-new story in the series, and it did just that despite its short length. While she got a bit of a redesign, Lara continued to be a great hero, the gameplay was fluid and satisfying, the puzzles were challenging yet fun, and it provided an adventure that rivaled the original trilogy.

Though the game was perhaps not considered on par with the original trilogy, Legend did break new ground in a different gaming generation. This 2006 game brought Lara back in a big way, setting up the franchise for more adventures to come in the future.

5 Tomb Raider: Anniversary (2007)

Fantastic Remake Of The Original Tomb Raider

Taking what they had done with Lara Croft in Legend , the developers chose to celebrate over ten years of the franchise with a game that acted as a remake of the very original entry. This resulted in Tomb Raider: Anniversary . As the rating suggests, Anniversary was well-received across the board, particularly the PC version. Anniversary acted as a special gift for both longtime fans of the series and those who wanted to get into the games, much like what Capcom has done recently with the Resident Evil franchise.

While nowhere near as iconic as the original Tomb Raider , Anniversary offers a fantastic refresh of a classic adventure, utilizing the changes seen in Legend to great effect. Due to being so different from the 1996 original, they are both worth playing regardless of someone's familiarity with them.

4 Tomb Raider 2 (1997)

Fine-Tuning A Masterpiece

After exploding to iconic status with the first game alone, it was only a year later that Lara Croft returned for a sequel that fans welcomed with open arms. Much in the same vein as Die Hard 2, the series avoided peaking in the second game, but it still managed to impress and make its money back.

Though some praised its challenging difficulty, there are those who have thought it was too hard in spots. In the end, though, Tomb Raider 2 is a nearly perfect follow-up to the classic original.

item.title: Skyrim: 10 Best Mods For Immersion
item.description:
Summary

  • Point The Way adds road signs for better navigation in Skyrim , enhancing immersion.
  • Immersive Patrols adds faction patrols for dynamic encounters, enriching the world.
  • Relationship Dialogue Overhaul adds voiced lines to NPCs, reducing repetition for enhanced immersion.

The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim is one of the largest and most popular open-world RPGs on the planet. The fifth major entry in the Elder Scrolls Series, Skyrim offers an expansive and detailed open-world that holds many hours of content. Be it through exploration, questing, or combat, Skyrim allows the player to take on a sprawling fantasy setting.

Skyrim is known for its modding support and community, wherein many of its shortcomings are improved upon or overhauled entirely by dedicated mod creators. One such category is immersion , in which there are plenty of mod creators who make mods to subtly increase the level of immersion players feel when exploring the vast world. These elements are often carefully designed in-keeping with the base game and simply serve to naturally overhaul the immersion of the Skyrim experience.

10 Point The Way

Adds Road Signs To The World

  • Mod Creator : Arthmoor
  • Mod Page : Point The Way

Skyrim's roads, while plentiful and fleshed out, are very clearly designed with map navigation in mind. While each road leads somewhere, but they require the player's map to know exactly where each one leads, a somewhat immersion-breaking element.

Point The Way aims to fix this issue in a simplistic but highly immersive manner. The mod adds road signs along the roads and at crossroads, pointing toward nearby towns and settlements. This makes sense from a world-building perspective and adds a small but effective sense of immersion to the experience of traversing the world.

9 Immersive Patrols

Adds More Military/Faction Patrols

  • Mod Creator : Scrabbulor
  • Mod Page : Immersive Patrols

The base game of Skyrim has random encounters that somewhat act as military patrols, wherein the Imperials can be found transporting a Stormcloak prisoner. This is the only instance of dynamic military mobilization, however. In an area torn apart by the civil war, it makes sense for there to be far more patrols.

This is where the mod Immersive Patrols shines. It includes random faction patrols, including Imperials, Stormcloaks, Thalmor, Dawnguard, and more. These patrols can dynamically engage the environment and create unique and immersive encounters along the roads of Skyrim.

8 Tamrielic Names

Names All Unnamed NPCs

  • Mod Creator : sasnikol
  • Mod Page : Tamrielic Names

Skyrim has a plethora of named NPCs who are fleshed-out, with dialogue options and sometimes quests. This creates the sense of an immersive and living world. However, not all NPCs have names, as a lot of them possess generic titles rather than actual names.

Tamrielic Names is a simple mod that aims to remedy this. It changes the names of previously unnamed NPCs to lore-friendly names. For example, once unnamed city guards will now have their own personalized name. This is a subtle but immersive change that makes Skyrim feel a little bit more lived-in and realistic.

7 Joy Of Perspective

Improves First Person View

  • Mod Creator : LogicDragon
  • Mod Page : Joy of Perspective

Skyrim is a game often played in third-person due to the nature of its first-person camera. The first-person perspective lacks immersion and doesn't allow the player to see all of the armor their character has equipped at any given time.

Joy of Perspective is a simple mod that allows the player to look down in the first-person perspective and see their body. This not only adds a level of logic and immersion to the first-person viewpoint, but allows the player to actually see the gear their Dragonborn is wearing. It's a very welcome feature in a game that allows for such visual customization.

6 Talkative Dragons

Allows For All Dragons To Talk

  • Mod Creator : Voeille
  • Mod Page : Talkative Dragons

The dragons in the Elder Scrolls series are incredibly intelligent and ancient beings. Each dragon speaks in the Thu'um and communicates as humans would, possessing the ability to have logical conversations. Some dragons in the main story possess this ability too, such as Anduin or Paarthurnax.

Despite this, no other dragons encountered in the wild ever use their voice. This makes little sense, given the sapient nature of Elder Scrolls dragons. As such, Talkative Dragons allows any dragon to talk, featuring combat voice lines to improve player immersion and to be in line with the lore.

5 Immersive Interactions

Gives The Player Character Context Relevant Animations

  • Mod Creator : JaySerpa
  • Mod Page : Immersive Interactions

Despite its many features and systems, Skyrim is somewhat lacking in its animations. Many items can simply be picked up or interacted with, without any delay or animation. Unlike Red Dead Redemption 2 , for example, which plays an animation when the player interacts with items in the game world, Skyrim is more hands-off.

Immersive Interactions remedies this issue by adding many interaction animations. Now, when the player picks up items, speaks to NPCs, interacts with animals, and does many other actions, context-relevant animations play. This is a small but immersive detail that enriches the experience.

4 Bandit Lines Expansion

Gives Bandits More Lines Of Dialogue

  • Mod Creator : JaySerpa
  • Mod Page : Bandit Lines Expansion

One of the most common types of enemy throughout Skyrim is the bandit. Bandits are often low-level enemies that occupy caves and encampments, attempting to rob or simply kill the player as they come close. Bandits are known for their limited voice lines, often yelling generic combat lines such as the infamous "You never should have come here!"

Bandit Lines Expansion solves the issue of generic bandit lines by adding nearly 500 new lines of dialogue. These can be combat lines or idle dialogue lines that give the bandits personality or motivation. This characterizes the generic bandits in the game, giving them more immersive motivations and intentions.

3 Immersive Citizens - AI Overhaul

Improves The AI Of Friendly NPCs

  • Mod Creator : Arnaud dOrchymont
  • Mod Page : Immersive Citizens - AI Overhaul

There are many NPCs in Skyrim , and many of them have activities to do and daily cycles they operate on. Most NPCs have dialogue options or quest relevance, meaning the player spends a lot of time engaging with, or in close proximity to, the NPCs.

With this in mind, Immersive Citizens - AI Overhaul improves the AI of the NPCs and makes them feel more lifelike and believable. This is especially noticeable when it comes to combat, wherein NPCs will intelligently evaluate danger. The mod also gives NPCs more travel options and a more immersive schedule, which makes towns feel more alive and lived-in.

2 Relationship Dialogue Overhaul

Increases The Amount Of NPC Dialogue

  • Mod Creator : cloudedtruth
  • Mod Page : Relationship Dialogue Overhaul

Dialogue in Skyrim , especially with friendly NPCs and followers, can become slightly grating. Many NPCs utter the same lines and possess the same dialogue options, meaning having a follower can be immersion-breaking due to the constant repeated dialogue.

Relationship Dialogue Overhaul adds 5000 lines of voiced dialogue to friendly NPCs, followers, spouses, and rivals. This is an instantly noticeable change that increases the immersion in Skyrim tenfold. When running through towns or traveling with followers, there will be significantly less line repetition, which makes the experience far more immersive and realistic.

1 Skyrim's Got Talent

Adds A Fleshed-Out Bard System

  • Mod Creator : JaySerpa
  • Mod Page : Skryim's Got Talent

The base Skyrim game includes a short storyline where the Dragonborn can join the Bards College, a college famous in the lore for birthing many notable musicians of Tamriel. This is an interesting prospect that is woefully underutilized and allows for no dynamic learning of instruments, instead resorting to standard dungeon-crawling quests.

Skyrim's Got Talent is an incredibly well-made and immersive mod that aims to remedy this. This mod allows the Dragonborn to learn an instrument and slowly improve at their chosen craft. It adds more songs, dynamic NPC reactions, and a whole new Bard progression system. This feature fits seamlessly into the main game and provides a new immersive and lore-friendly avenue of gameplay.
